articles.headline: Obama Signs Pact in Kabul, Turning Page in Afghan War
articles.snippet: President Obama, speaking to an American television audience from an air base in Kabul, said he had traveled there to herald a new era in the relationship between the United States and Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: President Obama, speaking to an American television audience from an air base in Kabul, said he had traveled there to herald a new era in the relationship between the United States and Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Obama, speaking to an American television audience on Tuesday night from Bagram Air Base, declared that he had traveled here to herald a new era in the relationship between the United States and Afghanistan, “a future in which war ends, and a new chapter begins.”

articles.headline: China’s Vanishing Trade Imbalance
articles.snippet: As the Strategic and Economic Dialogue with China convenes this week, the United States will have a harder time proving that its deficit is China’s fault.
articles.abstract: As the Strategic and Economic Dialogue with China convenes this week, the United States will have a harder time proving that its deficit is China’s fault.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s economic imbalance with China has been a singular concern of policy makers for more than half a decade. Senators Charles E. Schumer and Lindsey Graham wanted to punish China for pegging the exchange rate to the dollar in 2005 — arguing that its policy of cheapening the currency to subsidize exports was fueling a huge trade surplus that cost America jobs.

articles.headline: Chesapeake to Replace Chairman
articles.snippet: Chesapeake Energy announced that it would replace Aubrey K. McClendon as chairman and end his controversial compensation plan.
articles.abstract: Chesapeake Energy announced that it would replace Aubrey K. McClendon as chairman and end his controversial compensation plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Aubrey K. McClendon built Chesapeake Energy into the nation’s second-largest producer of natural gas through a combination of debt, foresight, luck and sheer bravado.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Once an Ambitious Law Firm, Reduced to Grim Dispatches
articles.snippet: The slow economy and cost-cutting at companies have hurt many of the nation’s law firms, including Dewey & LeBoeuf.
articles.abstract: The slow economy and cost-cutting at companies have hurt many of the nation’s law firms, including Dewey & LeBoeuf.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few dozen students from some of the nation’s top law schools received a distressing e-mail last Friday from Dewey & LeBoeuf. The law firm’s 2012 summer internship program, which would have paid the students more than $3,000 a week, was being canceled.

articles.headline: Pfizer Races to Reinvent Itself
articles.snippet: With its best-selling drugs losing patent protection, Pfizer is shedding money-making but noncore businesses to focus on pharmaceutical sciences.
articles.abstract: With its best-selling drugs losing patent protection, Pfizer is shedding money-making but noncore businesses to focus on pharmaceutical sciences.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, drug companies have known that their days of plenty were numbered, that the moment would arrive when the best-selling drugs that had driven two decades’ worth of profits would lose their patent protection and succumb to competition from generic alternatives. Without new blockbusters to replace them, profits would tumble.

articles.headline: In Pursuit of Mayor Bloomberg, the Reluctant Endorser
articles.snippet: Though President Obama and Mitt Romney publicly disagree with New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on a range of issues, they are both determined to score his endorsement.
articles.abstract: Though President Obama and Mitt Romney publicly disagree with New York Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on a range of issues, they are both determined to score his endorsement.
articles.lead_paragraph: They court him over coffee and drop by when they are in town. They dangle invitations for golf and enlist friends to put in a good word.

articles.headline: Chinese Dissident Is Released From Embassy, Causing Turmoil for U.S.
articles.snippet: While the blind lawyer Chen Guangcheng gave varying reasons for leaving American protection, he maintained that he did not feel that he and his family would be safe in China.
articles.abstract: While the blind lawyer Chen Guangcheng gave varying reasons for leaving American protection, he maintained that he did not feel that he and his family would be safe in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In a series of dramatically conflicting developments on Wednesday, the Chinese dissident Chen Guangcheng left American custody under disputed circumstances, and what briefly looked like a deft diplomatic achievement for Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton turned into a potential debacle.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: European Regulators May Reopen Street View Inquiries
articles.snippet: Revelations in the United States that a Google employee had informed colleagues that his program would collect personal data has cast doubt on the company’s excuses.
articles.abstract: Revelations in the United States that a Google employee had informed colleagues that his program would collect personal data has cast doubt on the company’s excuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — European privacy regulators said Wednesday that they were considering reopening their inquiries into Google’s collection of personal e-mails and Web searches for its Street View service. The move came after revelations that the activity had not been a lone programmer’s error, and that others at the company had been told about it.
